column1: Bothell () is a city in King and Snohomish counties in the U.S. state of Washington. It is part of the Seattle metropolitan area. As of the 2010 census it had a population of 33

column2: the Sammamish River valley from Lake Washington to Issaquah Creek south and upstream of Lake Sammamish was inhabited by a population of as many as 200 Native Americans known as the Sammamish people. The Sammamish were relocated after the Puget Sound War in 1856 to reservations and non-reservation lands.In 1870
column3: Columbus S. Greenleaf and George R. Wilson filed land claims in the area formerly inhabited by the Sammamish near present-day Bothell
column4: and built homes. Eight families followed over the next six years. In 1876
column5: Canadian George Brackett bought land and began commercial logging out of a camp located on the north bank of the Sammamish River in what is now the heart of downtown Bothell. A store
column7: and sawmill followed over the next several years.

column2: Brackett sold 80 acres (32 ha) to David Bothell
column3: a settler from Pennsylvania. The town's first postmaster
column4: who bought his property from Bothell
column5: named the town in his honor when it was platted in 1888. Later that same year
column6: a local railroad was built through the town to transport coal from Issaquah. Bothell was officially incorporated on April 14
column7: 1909.Bothell continued to grow as logging expanded and boat traffic brought increasing amounts of goods and passengers up and down the river. As more people moved into the area
column8: the Army Corps of Engineers decided to dredge and straighten the river in the years shortly after Bothell's incorporation. Most boat traffic came to an abrupt end only a few years later when Lake Washington was lowered in 1917. Water transport also shifted to trucks after a brick road was built from Seattle. The logging economy declined quickly around the same time
column9: and the local economy shifted to farming.After World War II

column1: Bothell has a temperate oceanic climate
column2: with cool summers and cool (but not cold) winters. Winter sees much more rainfall than summer and winters in Bothell (much like those in the rest of the Pacific Northwest) are very cloudy and overcast. Summers are drier and cool to warm.

column1: Bothell is home to Cascadia College and the University of Washington
column2: Bothell. The two institutions share the same campus
column3: which opened in the year 2000. In 2014 the University of Washington Bothell was ranked #37 in the nation among all colleges and universities by Money Magazine and was ranked 6th in the Nation by Washington Monthly in their "Best Bang for the Buck" rankings of colleges and universities. After becoming accredited in 2006 Cascadia College was named the second best community college in the nation
column4: behind Atlanta Technical College. UW Bothell has an enrollment of over 6
column6: of which 13 percent are from Snohomish County.Schools for Bothell students in grades kindergarten through 12th grade are part of the Northshore School District while private schools include Cedar Park Christian Schools serving preschool through 12th grade. Heritage Christian Academy serving kindergarten through 9th grades. Schools in Northshore School district include Fernwood Elementary
column21: and Secondary Academy for Success. North Creek High School opened in the North Creek area of the city in 2017.

column1: Bothell has a council–manager government governed by a city council consisting of seven council members
column2: each of whom is elected to a four-year term. Council elections are held every two years
column3: with either three or four positions standing
column4: depending upon the class. All positions are nonpartisan and at-large. The Council passes ordinances and resolutions
column7: and elects from its own membership a mayor and deputy mayor for two-year terms.Day-to-day affairs in the city are administered by a City Manager hired by the council. The current city manager is Jennifer Phillips and the mayor is Liam Olsen.
